content.description: Start just left of the warm-up on the face seen from the approach. Start with your right hand on a slightly incut, good undercling down and left of the large ledge and your left hand pinching the left arête, level with your right hand starting hold. Maneuver using some awkward foot holds and compression moves to trend up the face, and then make a jump (or reach, depending on your height) up to a good edge towards the top. Find foot holds, and get your hands up to jugs at the boulder’s apex in order to top out.
content.location: On the taller of the two boulders, it is located on the east face. Find the obvious ramp downclimb, and move left to the first vertical face.

content.description: Start on the obvious, large, juggy ledge low on the right side of the boulder (when looking from the approach). Make a move up to some great slopers/jugs, and cruise the vague, less-than-vertical arête to top out.
content.location: On the East side (approach side) of the taller boulder, start on the obvious, large, juggy ledge.

climbs.name: Not All It's Cracked Up To Be

content.description: Start low on the obvious, diagonal crack as for “EZPZ,” and work up and right following the crack to the right side of the boulder. Top out at the end of the crack.
content.location: It ascends the obvious, diagonal crack on the east (approach side) of short and stout boulder.

content.description: Start towards the left side on the obvious crack seen from the approach. Move straight up on good holds, and top out.
content.location: It is on the East face (approach side) of the shorter boulder.

content.description: Start with your left hand on the less-than-vertical arête and your right hand at the lowest point of a vertical crack on the south face. Move straight up on compression moves and bad foot holds. Naturally, the shelf beneath the block is off for your feet.
content.location: It is on the West face of the taller boulder (the opposite side from where you approach).Looking at the downclimb ramp, move right around the tree, and you're there.

content.description: Arachnophobia is short and sweet, has awesome movement, and is kept from getting 4 stars only due to only being a few moves. Start low and matched (you should see a good hold two-thirds of the way down the crack), and work up the overhanging crack to top out on the left. This is super lowball. Watch for spiders.The scrunchy start may be tougher to establish for taller folks.
content.location: Circle the shorter boulder to the right side to the overhung crack next to the tree. It is located on its northern face.

content.description: These are two boulders. When approaching via Streeter Trail, the boulder on the left is a bit taller and has 4 unique routes, which I will input shortly. The boulder to the right is shorter but still has a few routes - mostly warm-ups with a couple cool crack systems.
